job_title: Pharmacy Technician in New York, NY
pros: The pharmacy dept is relaxed
cons: Sometimes lack of staff and overall directions

job_title: Intern in New York, NY
pros: - Learn a lot - Hands on experience - Exposure to different parts of hospital setting
cons: - Low pay - Very busy (however periods that are slower too)

review_title: Great Pay Now I Understand Why
job_title: Radiologic Technologist in New York, NY
pros: Hss is top paying hospital for xray techs (I dnt believe this counts for CT techs)
cons: The cassettes are heavy and the radiologist make you do back breaking views (merchant and cross table with calibration markers and standing ankles ) on majority of the patients so all the technologist have what seems like assigned surgeons to take care of the slip disks and such. The EOS machines are over used to the point where floor fans from dollar tree are blown to keep the machine from over heating because youre not allowed to open the window. You get asked to skip lunch almost everyday. Calibration markers are put in between patients legs even male patients while standing if you could imagine. Male patients sexually harrass the women techs and are very entitled in that way and your supposed to just get used to it. Most techs like the OR better to avoid the back breaking stress the floor brings. No where to sit whilst on portables so techs sit in stair cases and nooks. Hss has long wait times and double sometimes triple book the room you occupy.

job_title: Associate Accounts Receivable in New York, NY
pros: Easy work, very little headaches or mental stress
cons: Work culture is toxic, co-workers spying and reporting you to the manager/ supervisor. A lot of office politics/ and lack of opportunities to advance into a better position.

job_title: Office Manager in New York, NY
pros: nice employees- good work culture
cons: management sucks/ okay benefits/burn out

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Best place I ever worked. Great manager and culture.
cons: Projects moved slowly. Not much else.

job_title: Pharmacy Technician in New York, NY
pros: Good pay. Good benefits pretax and after tax, cheaper that other employers. Downtime in the pharmacy, not busy if you are down to do your job.
cons: Human Resources is there to give you a hard time on everything, and runs arounds or anything. They dont work with you, they work for the hospital. Always get everything on email and not on the phone. And if you get injured or need any accommodations please make sure to report it, because if not that will be a big issue. No room to growth for pharmacy technicians and management does not care to provide or create opportunities. Schedule hours. Job responsibilities. Pharmacy management was the worst, still continues the worst. Toxic environment, a lot of gossiping, without counting on the favorites the managers have. Make sure you recognize your good employees, just like you have an environment where everybody wants to come to work and is not just doing it for the money.

job_title: Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Friendly environment, tuition reimbursement, great benefits
cons: Not much room for growth

job_title: Patient Access Specialist in New York, NY
pros: We have some of the most incredible HSS employees. I am incredibly proud to say that I am surrounded by the most amazing clinicians and admins who love their work and go above and beyond despite feeling exhausted and burnt out.
cons: I do feel that we are very understaffed our PAS staffed is overworked and under appreciated. We are constantly scrutinized and feel the weight of having to fill schedules and meet HSS unrealistic workload but also expected to do our work. I hate to leave a bad review but I would never recommend anyone work under these conditions. I can only imagine that this place will crumble if upper management does not wake up and realize the value of their Admin staff. We are not paid enough and they will continue to lose staff if more is not done.

job_title: Assistant Manager in New York, NY
pros: Good pay. Good overall morale. High bar set for professionalism, best practices and education. Patient care is #1
cons: If you're not willing to blow smoke up your manager's butt don't expect a promotion. It's all a game of politics. Not what you know but who you kiss up to.

review_title: The Best Hospital to work for!

Patients receiving great care

Benefits

In the latter, you can reapply quickly but it seems a waste of everyone's time and resources to have the lapse.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN) in New York, NY
pros: the 3 top hospitals in NYC is HSS, NYP and MSK.... if you are here you made it, and that's a fact. The beauty of HSS is the specialization in the field of Orthopedics and Rheumatology; so rarely sick patients which is less stress on nurses.
cons: new nurses is great at the beginning then begin to slack after, cause working here is really so fun that sometimes if not most of the time they complain on the littlest thing, like "why are they sending me to the second floor, why can they just leave me alone browsing the internet and shopping because I'm not doing anything... really lame. Cons is more of the lazy nurses versus the hospital itself.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: I have never felt more genuinely supported and cared for at work - this is really an amazing place.
cons: A little slow in terms of efficiency and innovation. If you are someone who thrives under pressure, this is not the place for you.

job_title: Patient Access Specialist II in New York, NY
pros: The Hospital tries to make their employees feel valued and heard. They offer different services to help you in times of need as well. The culture here gives you a feeling of pride to say you work for HSS. You will work with some passionate team members and depending on your role and leadership, be pushed to be better.
cons: As I've gained experience and knowledge I have been able to see the change in how we operate more like a corporation and less as a family feeling team. I have seen the impact in team members, which has led to some dissatisfaction in their roles. Also not every position allows for growth financially, but HSS has been consistent with 3% raises, yearly, to offset inflation. You may find yourself looking outside of HSS using them as a strong part of your resume to get closer to the pay you are looking for.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in New York, NY
pros: Great people and lots of teamwork. Friendly environment and great pay with benefits. This hospital really looks out for their employees and appreciate them.
cons: Transitions are not easy. If you obtain a higher degree in nursing, it is very hard to transition to a new position. You must have 1yr RN experience in order to qualify for any openings here and the residency program is very competitive and its not guaranteed you will get in. Most LPN's resign and persue careers at other hospitals and then try to return in a year or two with RN experience.

job_title: Patient Access Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Great training for new hire.
cons: There’s a lot of racism going on in the rehabilitation department in the main hospital. Managers and directors promote whomever they want even though employees don’t meet the qualifications .The director is behind all and acts as if she cares but it’s all lies, I’ve seen many things and I’ve heard many awful things said about employees. It’s crazy how in the world we live in we still have to face with discrimination at work. I hope things change for the better.

job_title: Clinical Nutritionist in New York, NY
pros: It's a beautiful hospital in a great location in NYC. The per diem rate for RDs is pretty good compared to other clinical jobs. The hours are reasonable, if you're willing to "leave your work at the door" at the end of the day. If you're looking for a fairly straightforward job, that doesn't particularly challenge you intellectually, and you want a position where you can put in the hours, and not think about work once you leave at the end of the day, then this place is for you.
cons: Many of the managers are in their positions because they've simply put the time in with the hospital - not because they're particularly qualified. Management in the Food & Nutrition Dept. lack the ability to recognize and maximize the potential in their employees, leading to intense frustration among staff and limited opportunities for growth. Decisions are often made on a personal basis, instead of a professional basis. There are LIMITED opportunities for growth and advancement - an issue raised with HR, to no avail.

pros: Not your typical hospital, mostly elective surgery. Good people to work with
cons: Recently a lot of changes in upper management

job_title: Clinical Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: great experience for pre-med students
cons: There aren't really any cons just a very busy environment

job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY

review_title: If you are looking for career advancement, keep looking.
job_title: in New York, NY
pros:
- salary is competitive, especially for middle and upper management
- benefits are very good
- vacation time is very good
cons:
- career development is almost non-existent
- employees treated as disposable
- employee morale is very low
- technology is very very behind
- middle and upper management have a severe lack of knowledge of new technologies (even when that is their field)
- they do not adopt new platforms and technologies until they are miles behind the competition
- zero work/life balance. Your family is expected to take a backseat to HSS
- management often does not listen to employees opinons and ideas even if it is what they were hired for as "experts"
- often when advancement opportunities come up, they hire outside instead of promoting from within
- feedback on projects often focuses on the negative and almost never the positive

job_title: Billing Manager in New York, NY
pros: They promote positivity. They always have fun goodies for the staff.
cons: Too many meetings and not enough time to complete projects.

job_title: Senior Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits, Research Experience, PTO
cons: Lower pay than other hospitals

job_title: Program Manager in New York, NY
pros: Great environment and mentoring here.
cons: None that I can think of.

review_title: dissapointed employees, morale is at all-time low
job_title: Nurse in New York, NY
pros: Staff (not admin) is wonderful. Pay and benefits are comparable to others in the city. Clean hospital. Supplies are always available. Decent vacation time (they encourage us to use it)
cons: Administration does not care about staff. They only worry about their reputation, improving scores, receiving Magnet. We are micromanaged on a large scale. We have ZERO autonomy. Some middle managers care but their hands are tied by the high level administrators, who are bullies. Surgeons are treated like gods, who can make large mistakes, yet we are expected to be perfect or we get fired. Patients can treat us like garbage and we are expected to sacrifice our dignity and self-respect to make them happy. All for good scores. We are discouraged from using our sick time. Sick time policy is unrealistic. We are incredibly understaffed, yet the expectations and standards remain at the highest level. We are scared to speak up. Speak up, become a target. If they don't like you, watch out. We are expected to be transport team while caring for patients. Charge nurses are leaving because the pressure it too high, with zero reward. We get no recognition, positive feedback, rewards of any kind. Not even for nurses week.

review_title: I learned a lot. However, most of the physicians are disrespect and unappreciated of LPNs hard work

pros: Great benefits and hourly rate
cons: Management is unorganized and they show a lot of favoritism

job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY

job_title: Manager in New York, NY

review_title: Not good for women or progressive people
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: If you want a very standard, bureaucratic work environment that offers stability, but not much in the way of feeling like your contribution matters, this may be a good fit for you. You'll get a consistent paycheck.
cons:
- Leadership is very set in their ways.
- You have to fit in with their ethos, completely.
- Disrespectful of women, even though there are women in management positions. The women take a deferring stance to the men, and particularly, the male doctors.
- If you are woman, you won't get ahead by being empowered. You have to act submissive and stroke egos.
-They value position and time served with the hospital more than aptitude and skill. So people get promoted into positions they really either aren't qualified for, or over time, their skills become irrelevant but since they are management, nothing is done.

If literally, in my entire life, never worked in such a tip-toe environment for women, to literally be told to dress differently (and I don't dress provocatively) and not speak my mind.

review_title: Great place to work as long as you're part of the medical staff
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Excellent benefits and time off, pride in the mission to get people mobile again.  Annual cost of living increase is appreciated.
cons: Not many opportunities for advancement unless you buddy up to higher management or earn a Masters degree (they love those to the detriment of perfectly qualified internal candidates).  The CEO is aggressive and management seems to be full of "yes men" (and women) who do a poor job of acting for the benefit of their employees' sanity.   Their Press Ganey employee satisfaction surveys are a joke - everyone eventually gives high grades because they don't want to endlessly review why certain elements scored badly.

review_title: Good place to work with excellent benefits
job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros: HSS has amazing benefits.  The number of weeks of vacation that you're given depending on position is probably one of the highest that I've ever heard of.  Another benefit is that you are praised for a job well done and management is good about communicating anything major going on with the hospital.
cons: The lack of career opportunities is probably the only disadvantage that I see.  Most people stay with the hospital for years and years, and this means that you can't really advance.  Once in a while you will see a job posted but that's about it.  There is no career ladder or any pre-determined way to advance in the hospital.

review_title: An good place to work with great vacation package!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Prestigous hospital with very good benefits.  Salary wage is pretty decent. An instituion with that tries to live up to their name. Usually there is a pay raise every year.
cons: Promotions are not easily come by.  You can easily be looked over and find yourself training someone for the position you are qualified for.  You will be given an excuse that the person is coming in to add something new to the position and that this person knows how to do something new that is now required for the position, which is totally not the case.  There is no loyalty.

review_title: It has been an incredible ride - the hardest I have ever worked and the best, most rewarding job I have ever had.
job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros: Fabulous brand, available reosurces, opportunities to do what I do best everyday, collegial relationships, and environment of excellence and innovation.
cons:
Location and commute, limited promotional opportunities, unrelenting pace and volume of work  and lack of work/life balance.

If you can handle the demands for total commitment - it is a fabulous place to work!

job_title: Physician Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
Great pay with night or weekend differential. 
Set schedule that never rotates; if you work 3 days a week then you have time for a second job 
Good benefits if your full time 
Great place to be towards the end of your clinical career; a lot of patients but doesn't take much medical management
cons:
Client happiness is all that matters with this institution, even if its not in the best of interest. 
You work with a very wealthy population that have more power than you in this hospital 
Not a good learning institution unless your a resident, fellow or Physical therapist. Not a good learning place for new PAs or RNs

job_title: Practice Manager in New York, NY
pros: Most employees have a pro-team mentality, and will go that extra mile to improve patient experience. Benefits are great.
cons: Physicians are not held accountable by administration when major employment laws are broken. Employees are pressured to keep quiet when errors by clinicians might endanger patient care.

job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY
pros: Patients are lower acuity than other hospitals. Excellent coworkers below management. It can feel like a family there outside of management. 18-20 days of vacation with time to use it.  Tuition reimbursement.
cons: This place should be unionized. They treat the nurses badly and never back them up when they should. Management is disconnected from their Magnet nurses. The moral of the nursing staff is lower than it has been in a long time.

review_title: My personal experience employed at HSS for 5 years was great until cronyism reared it's head.
job_title: Data Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: The myriad of issues that one would expect from a radiology dept upgrading from a mini-PACS system to full-PACS allowed me to hone my skills to resolve their IT related quickly and concisely.
cons:
-Managers hired because of their relationship with other senior managers not because of some skill set they posses. 
-Subordinates would have to deal with petty, mean interactions with management. Management would make it a point to harass someone just because they were in a position of power. Almost like a bully in school would knock another's student plate of food at lunch.  Management would actively sabotage the work of subordinates in order to start a paper trail against them.

job_title: Practice What You Preach! in New York, NY
pros: Physicians here are treated like kings.
cons: HSS is frustratingly slow at implementing clinical and administrative information technology. There's plenty of talk and not enough action. Advancement in your career will be grim unless you're friendly with a high-level manager. HSS says they value employee feedback but be advised not to ruffle upper management's feathers.

job_title: RN Case Manager in New York, NY
pros: Professional staff, friendly environment, high-quality leadership.  Great benefits and time off. Excellent, competitive pay.
cons: None that comes to mind.

review_title: Don't work here unless you are an MD

pros:
good pay
people are generally nice and approachable
lots of informal parties
cons:
conservative
10 years behind the digital/computer age
department culture
lack of diversity in senior management
few (maybe none) professional networks
CEO is innovative, but the doers are not. they are old and have been there a long time...

review_title: Ok job for the mean time... until they get tired if you.
job_title: Patient Care Assistant in New York, NY
pros: General pleasantness amongst the facility as a whole, great benefits, and great composition for nurses.
cons: Horrible employee morale amongst nurses, lots of back stabbing, and incompetent management on all levels in nursing.

review_title: Good place to work for but without career paths for staff

cons:

There are not career paths for staff, never saw anyone getting a promotion, the organization always recruits new people for open positions

review_title: Monitoring Sensory and Motor potentials during spine surgery
job_title: Intraoperative Neuromonitoring Tech in New York, NY
pros: Absolutely amazing environment everyone is so genuine and humble in the hospital is like a country club. The intraoperative monitoring department is in house and their training is exponentially better than any third-party company
cons: Schedule wise is a day by day basis meaning you don’t know what your schedule is really going to be like the day of which affects your social life

review_title: If you are medical staff, working with doctors can be a pain
job_title: Software Developer in New York, NY
pros: Laid back environment, some level of stress and intensity, good culture (patients first)
cons: Many Doctors are arrogant (I am sure it's not just this hopsital), working with them can be a pain if you dont have the same level of educations they have (doctoral)

job_title: Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Hospital attracts the top talent of the Industry, hands down.  If you're a go getter, the opportunities are endless if you can bring ideas to the table.
cons: HSS is a victim of its own success - it's so tremendously successful that they have challenges handling the influx of patients that arrive or wish to schedule appts.

review_title: A great place to work if you're in the right department
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: I feel very fortunate that I worked in a semi-small department where I felt my opinion was valued and I was given respect from the first day.
cons: Change is hard to come by. There's a long path to upper management.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Friendly and personable HR; benefits and PTO are good if you're in the right position and able to actually utilize them; some managers are great (but are largely overshadowed by ones who are not); pretty effective internal systems, considering the size and number of staff
cons: Work-life balance in administrative positions is non-existent.  Certain administrative departments have total immunity and run the hospital as a business, rather than foster an environment of welfare and healthcare.   Favoritism runs abound and lower level employees are expected to cater to and kiss up to physicians and senior management, to the point of questionable ethics.  The "culture" at the hospital is deplorable - individualism is largely discouraged and suppressed, and while a "diverse" staff is boasted, the diversity is purely ethnic and is only encouraged as long as your personality and approach is entirely in line with what senior management expects of it.  Arrogance runs abound, apparently due to the name and reputation of the hospital.  Overall, the working conditions for those who aren't considered golden becomes insufferable to the point where certain positions see extremely high turnover due to overwork and the inability to take advantage of generous PTO (which is awarded in vain).  There are very few young employees outside of secretarial and administrative  assistant positions, which is essentially due to the inability of senior management to catch up to current technological and cultural practices in the workplace.

review_title: this ain't a real hospital. more like a fancy hotel with pretty young nurses
job_title: Nurse in New York, NY
pros: each floor is staffed with hardworking, motivated young nurses (so sad, they don't know any better.  they will never fulfill their potential here)
cons: if you want to succeed here, you really don't need any clinical skills, just be able to speak the right language and ingratiate yourself to the right people, er, surgeons.

review_title: We have everything we need to do the job.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: I've been working for over 18 years and was never bored.  Hi profile clientele, supportive environment , great hospital recourses make a big difference in your employment experience. We have everything we need to do the job.

job_title: in New York, NY

review_title: Great hospital, staff, and culture. 3.5 Stars
